title-group.article-title: Classification of Crangonyx islandicus (Amphipoda, Crangonyctidae) based on morphological characters and comparison with molecular phylogenies

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Classification of Crangonyx islandicus ( Amphipoda , Crangonyctidae ) based on morphological characters and comparison with molecular phylogenies
ETIENNE KORNOBIS 1 , SNAEBJÖRN PÁLSSON & JÖRUNDUR SVAVARSSON
Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Iceland , 101 Reykjavik, Iceland
1 Corresponding author. E-mail: etk1@hi.is

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Crangonyx islandicus is a groundwater amphipod species endemic to Iceland and a member of the family Crangonyctidae which is widespread throughout the Holarctic region. A previous study based on variation in nuclear genes showed that C. islandicus closest relatives are Crangonyx species from North America, where most of the species diversity of the genus occurs. In this study, we aim at describing the morphological affinities of C. islandicus with North American Crangonyx species and two Eurasian species, C. chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus . We used the morphological characters defined by and scored them for different populations of C. islandicus as well as for C. chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus . The molecular phylogeny of the Crangonyctidae family and the morphological character states are compared in order to detect potential convergence in the morphological traits, common in subterranean species. C. islandicus appears to be close morphologically to C. subterraneus from Europe and C. longicarpus from North America. The morphological proximity of C. islandicus and C. subterraneus is incongruent with the pattern observed from molecular data.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Key words: Crustacea, groundwater, morphology, RNA, convergence, biogeography, colonization, Iceland

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Crangonyx islandicus Svavarsson & Kristjánsson, 2006 is a subterranean groundwater amphipod endemic to Iceland ( ). This species belongs to the freshwater family Crangonyctidae , currently widespread in the previously unglaciated Holarctic regions. The occurrence of C. islandicus in an island in the midst of the Atlantic Ocean which has repeatedly been covered by glaciers during the Ice Age has raised questions about its origin and colonization of Iceland . The genus Crangonyx contains 47 species, 42 of which occur in North America ( , , , ). Based on 18S and 28S nuclear RNA genes, Kornobis et al. (2011) showed that C. islandicus closest relatives are Crangonyx species from North America and concluded that it had probably colonized Iceland via an ancient land bridge between Greenland and Iceland .

Analyses of mtDNA of C. islandicus have revealed geographic patterns of variation in Iceland ( ). Populations along the volcanic region in Iceland are characterized by different monophyletic clades of the mtDNA genealogy, which have been diverging for 250 thousand years up to 5 Million years. The oldest branching includes the divergence of a single population in northeastern Iceland from the other populations. As populations from adjacent regions are generally more related than populations sampled at larger distances, concluded that the differentiation among the populations must had occurred within Iceland and thus that the species had survived repeated glaciation periods underneath glaciers.

The family Crangonyctidae , encompassing the genus Crangonyx , is an exclusively freshwater crustacean family and 80% of the species are hypogean ( ). Morphological characters affected by convergence or parallelism, e.g. reduced eyes and loss of pigmentation, have been commonly observed among subterranean species and were originally termed as “troglomorphic” by Christiansen (see ). These common features could obscure the phylogenetic relationships based on morphological data, particularly among the Crangonyx species. The phylogenies based on 18S and 28S revealed that Crangonyx is clearly polyphyletic (Kornobis et al. 2011). Two Crangonyx species from Eurasia, i.e. C. chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus , are more closely related to Bactrurus and Stygobromus than to the other species of the genus Crangonyx . noted that these two species seem to be closely related to the richmondensis and forbesi groups of North American Crangonyx , although they didn't incorporate these two species in their morphological phylogeny. Integrating C. subterraneus and C. chlebnikovi in this phylogeny will permit, in addition to evaluating their relationships to C. islandicus , to assess which morphological traits are susceptible to convergent or parallel evolution within the genus Crangonyx .

The relationship of C. islandicus with other Crangonyx species still remains poorly known. It differs in a few morphological characteristics, such as in lacking sternal gills/processes and in the spination of the maxilliped, from all other Crangonyx species. Phylogenetic analysis based on morphological traits are of particular interest to infer about its closest relatives in North America and in Europe. The extensive morphological analysis of the North American Crangonyx species by provides a framework for further analyses. The phylogenetic relationships could furthermore, provide information about the colonization route to Iceland either through contact with Greenland or an older path through Iceland-Faeroes-Scotland Ridge (see ).

The use of morphometric analysis in amphipods has been suggested to serve as a complement of description using traditional character keys ( ). A study on Niphargus amphipods showed that clades defined by molecular data can be diagnosed using morphometric analysis ( ). The overall size of species is known to be highly variable within Crangonyctidae (e.g. , , ) and may reflect variation in habitats. The variation in body size may reflect the phylogenetic relationships, where different lineages have occupied groundwater habitats with different pore sizes. The pore size may also have been an important selective factor on body size ( ) and resulted in convergence in body size and lack of phylogenetic dependence.

In this study, the main goal is to clarify the phylogenetic affinities of C. islandicus , particularly with North American species of Crangonyx , based on morphology and in comparison with a phylogeny based on molecular data. In addition we look for potential morphological differences between putative cryptic species of C. islandicus . Finally we determine whether size and other morphological traits depend on the phylogenetic relationships.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Morphological matrix. We used the 26 morphological characters defined by to evaluate the morphological affinities of C. islandicus from Iceland , C. chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus from Eurasia with the North American species of Crangonyx (see Table A 1 in supplementary material). Individuals were dissected and relevant appendages were mounted in glycerin for observation. In total, six individuals of C. islandicus (three from southern Iceland , and three from northern Iceland ), three of C. chlebnikovi and one of C. subterraneus were analyzed. The unique individual of C. subterraneus was a juvenile, known to be nearly identical morphologically to adult individual ( ). The descriptions of C. islandicus Svavarsson & Kristjánsson, 2006 and C. subterraneus (see ) were used to verify our scoring. No such precise description of the characters of interest was found for C. chlebnikovi .

In order to make comparison of phylogenetic trees based on morphological and nuclear data, we analyzed the morphological data from different genera. Appendages of three Synurella ambulans individuals were dissected and analyzed, and the morphological description of three Bactrurus (see ), three Stygobromus species (see ), Amurocrangonyx arsenjevi Sidorov & Holsinger, 2007 and Crymostygius thingvallensis Kristjánsson & Svavarsson, 2004 were used to score the character states defined by .

Phylogenetic trees. Trees based on morphology were reconstructed using cladistic and phenetic methods. The cladistic analysis was conducted with the program Pars from the Phylip 3.69 package ( ) using ordinary parsimony. Consensus tree obtained from the most parsimonious trees was computed with the program Consense in the Phylip package ( ). The phenetic analysis were realized using euclidean distances between species and the tree was reconstructed using the neighbor joining method implemented in the APE package ( ) in R (R Core Development ). Since no male individuals have been described so far for C. islandicus , trees were reconstructed using the complete dataset and a subset containing only character states based on female morphology. The outgroup used by for their morphological phylogeny was species from the genus Synurella . According to the phylogeny based on 18S and 28S for Crangonyctidae species, the genus Synurella is polyphyletic and might thus distort the phylogenetic relationships when considered as an outgroup. We therefore compared morphological phylogenies rooted with Synurella species as and Crymostygius thingvallensis , which is the closest relative of the Crangonyctidae family known so far (Kornobis et al. 2011).

Phylogenetic trees based on the 28S RNA gene for a small subset of the Crangonyctidae species were obtained from our previous study (Kornobis et al. 2011). A new Bayesian tree of the 18S gene was constructed using the same data as in Kornobis et al. (2011) and one additional 18S sequence from C. subterraneus (applying same methods as in Kornobis et al. 2011).

Phylogenetic dependence of size and morphological traits. Variation in size was compared to the phylogenetic trees by testing the correlation between the difference in maximum overall size of each species and each sex with the patristic distances for the trees obtained from morphological and molecular data with the Mantel test ( ). We tested also the phylogenetic dependence of species sizes with four tests based on the orthonormal transform method to decompose the variances in size, by avoiding the phylogenetic autocorrelation ( ), using the ade4 package ( ) in R. Sizes were obtained from the published descriptions ( , , , , , , , , ) and personal observations. Patristic distances were calculated using solely the topology of the tree since no branch lengths were available from the consensus trees. No data were available for male individuals for C. chlebnikovi , C. islandicus and C. thingvallensis and were therefore not included in the analysis.

Morphological scoring matrix based on both our data and data from the literature was superimposed on the morphological phylogeny, and both 18S and 28S molecular phylogenies using the APE package ( ) and R scripts. We compared morphological data to the molecular trees by assessing the association of the state of each of the 26 characters defined by with the two main clades defined by the trees. One clade is formed by Crangonyx and Synurella from North America and C. islandicus , the other clade by Stygobromus , Bactrurus species , C. chlebnikovi , C. subterraneus , Synurella ambulans and Amurocrangonyx arsenjevi . The association was quantified by using the odd ratio calculated for each character. Significance of the odd ratio was tested with a Fisher's exact test implemented in R.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Scoring matrix. Morphological states of the characters based on female morphology (20 out of 26 characters in total) were successfully scored for all species analyzed. Currently, no male individuals of C. islandicus have been identified and the three individuals analyzed from C. chlebnikovi were females. We observed no differences between the character states of individuals from the northeastern and southern populations of C. islandicus . The only individual of C. subterraneus available was a juvenile female. The state of the character 21, i.e. the number of spines on each dorsal lobe of the telson, for C. subterraneus was not fitting any of the scoring possibilities. The illustration of C. subterraneus made by shows 3 and 5 spines, respectively, on each lobe whereas the states for this character defined by Holsinger & are either more or less than 4 spines per lobe. Nonetheless, no changes were observed in the phylogenies when any of the possible states, i.e. 0, 1 or NA, were used for the scoring of this character for C. subterraneus .

Phylogenies based on morphology. Addition of the three Eurasian Crangonyx species ( C. islandicus , C. chlebnikovi , and C. subterraneus ) to the dataset used to construct the tree by and for the two different outgroups, did not have large impact on the tree ( Fig. 1 and 2 ). The three main groups, i.e. richmondensis, gracilis and shoemakeri, were still present. However C. baculispina and C. packardi from the gracilis group cluster with C. islandicus , C. subterraneus and C. longicarpus in the maximum parsimony phylogeny rooted with Synurella ( Fig 1 ). Trees based on a subset of characters (omitting male characters) showed little variation with the trees based on the complete set of characters, mainly giving less resolution in some external nodes of the tree but not affecting the phylogenetic relationships of C. islandicus , C. subterraneus and C. chlebnikovi with the North American Crangonyx . The trees based on the neighbor joining method showed some alterations compared to the one based on parsimony, but not in the phylogenetic relationships of the main groups defined by . These changes are C. longicarpus diverging earlier from other species of the gracilis group, C. chlebnikovi clustering with C. forbesi within the richmondensis group and the position in the tree of the ungrouped species ( Fig. A1 and A 2 in supplementary material). The trees present polytomies and the deepest phylogenetic relationships are poorly resolved and fluctuate between methods and the chosen outgroup (see also ). Nonetheless, all trees show that the richmondensis group diverged early from the two other main groups gracilis and shoemakeri. The tree rooted with Crymostygius thingvallensis shows the Synurella outgroup used by within the genus Crangonyx and present the genus Crangonyx as polyphyletic ( Fig. 2 ). The richmondensis group, C. chlebnikovi , C. forbesi , C. insolitus , C. antennatus , C. specus and C. serratus appeared in this case to have diverged early from the other Crangonyx species.

Phylogenies produced with the maximum parsimony method, regardless of which outgroup was used as a root, cluster C. islandicus with C. subterraneus and C. longicarpus , and a bit more distantly related are C. packardi and C. baculispina ( Fig. 1 and 2 ). The group formed by C. islandicus , C. subterraneus and C. longicarpus present a shared state in character 19 which distinguishes them from all other species from the gracilis group (see Table A 1 in supplementary material). In the phylogenies based on neighbor joining, C. islandicus shows more morphological affinities with C. subterraneus and C. packardi than with any other species.

In all phylogenies, C. chlebnikovi appears closely related either to C. forbesi or C. insolitus and more distantly to the richmondensis group ( Fig. 1 and 2 ). This is in accordance to the observation made by who described C. chlebnikovi as similar to the forbesi and richmondensis groups. All species from the richmondensis group, C. insolitus , C. forbesi and C. chlebnikovi present a shared derived state in the character 20 i.e. presenting a number of retinaculae on the pleiopod 1 of the female superior to 2. noted that C. subterraneus seems also closely allied morphologically to C. forbesi and the richmondensis group. This is not supported by our phylogeny which grouped C. subterraneus with C. islandicus .

Comparison with the molecular phylogeny. The phylogeny based on morphological characters and rooted with Crymostygius thingvallensis is more congruent with the phylogenies based on the molecular sequences than the tree rooted with Synurella ( Fig. 1 , 2 and 3 ). According to these phylogenies Crangonyx is polyphyletic and the Synurella species are more closely related to Crangonyx species than some Crangonyx species are to each other (e.g. the richmondensis and gracilis groups).

C. islandicus is more closely related to the North American species than to the two Eurasian ones, in both molecular phylogenies ( Fig. 3 , and Fig. A3 , A 4 in supplementary material). Based on morphology, C. islandicus appeared closely related to C. subterraneus which is not supported by the molecular data. Adding C. subterraneus (Genbank accession number: JQ277470 ) to the phylogeny based on 18S (presented previously in Kornobis et al. 2011) did not have a large impact on the tree and this species clusters with C. chlebnikovi whereas none of the phylogenies based on morphology display this grouping ( Fig. 1 , 2 and 3 ). C. chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus are also more closely related to each other than to C. islandicus or to the Crangonyx species from North America in the 28S phylogeny. Based on molecular data, these two species are clustering with species of the genus Bactrurus and Stygobromus ( Fig. 3 and Fig. A3 and A 4 in supplementary material) .

Phylogenetic dependence of size and morphological traits. The overall length of the Crangonyx species for males and females is highly correlated with the patristic distances from the two parsimony trees based on morphology according to the Mantel test and show clear phylogenetic dependence with all four tests based on the ortho- gram developed by ( Table 1 and Fig. 4 ). Both R2Max and Dmax tests were highly significant, showing that significant change in size of the Crangonyx can be traced mainly to one node at the base of the tree. Indeed, the forbesi and the richmondensis group, as noticed by , are the groups with the largest species and some species of the shoemakeri group show sizes intermediate between the richmondensis and gracilis groups ( Table 2 and Fig. 4 ).
species. r: Pearson's correlation coefficient, p: p values. The orthonormal test were defined by .

No clear association was observed between phylogenetic relationships among Crangonyctidae species based on molecular data and the maximum overall size of the species. The only tests close to being significant were the Mantel tests comparing the 28S phylogenies with males and females sizes ( Table 1 ). This could also be due to the limited taxon sampling available for these phylogenies or lack of phylogenetic information present in the overall size at the family level.

Correspondence of the morphological traits with the two main clades of the phylogenies based on 18S and 28S shows lack of any consistent pattern (see in supplementary Fig. A3 and A 4 ). None of the odd ratios showed significant association between morphological characters states and the clusters based on molecular data. This may be partly due to the small number of taxa available, especially for the 28S phylogeny, resulting in low statistical power. The logarithm of the odd ratios for all characters was generally low (less than 2.78) for the clades based on the 18S tree and less than 0.96 based on the 28S tree. Only two odd ratios for the 18S phylogeny i.e. for characters 8 and 21, and none for the 28S had p values less than 0.1. It is noteworthy that two of the three highest odd ratios correspond to characters based on the length ratio between carpus and propodus of gnathopods 1 and 2, supporting the notion that size is a phylogenetically conserved trait.

The relatively high genetic distances for the 18S and 28S genes between C. chlebnikovi and C. forbesi on one side and C. islandicus and C. subterraneus on the other, compared to their respective low morphological differences, can be seen as an example of convergent or parallel evolution in morphological traits. The state of characters 17 (the number of spines on the palmar margin of gnathopod 2) and 20 (the number of retinaculae on pleopod 1) are identical for C. chlebnikovi and C. forbesi , but different for the ones observed for Stygobromus and Bactrurus species and C. subterraneus .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The integration of the three Eurasian species in the phylogeny by did not affect the main phylogenetic relationships and the species groups defined by these authors. The only changes were that C. packardi and C. baculispina of the gracilis group clustered with C. islandicus in a well separated group. As noticed earlier, the characters give poor resolution for the deepest phylogenetic relationships. The morphological traits appear as well to have low phylogenetic resolution at the family level when compared with the molecular phylogenies. As defined by for the phylogeny of the North American Crangonyx , the traits are highly variable and may be more informative for differences within genera than among them. Consequently, these characters may not be suitable to evaluate the potential genus status of C. islandicus and for the redescription of the Crangonyx genus, considering the extensive genetic differentiation between C. chlebnikovi , C. subterraneus and the other Crangonyx species. C . chlebnikovi and C. subterraneus are currently being revised (Sidorov, unpublished).

The scoring of the character states used in this study were unable to distinguish C. islandicus individuals from the southern population from the northeastern populations (denoted group F in ) which were found to have highly divergent mtDNA types . Only a minor difference, with respect to number of mutations, was observed for the ITS1 and ITS2 regions (Kornobis and Pálsson, 2011) and the conservative 18S and 28S nuclear genes (Kornobis et al. 2011) between the two populations. Some species of Crangonyx from North America present the same states for the characters defined by (e.g. C. fontinalis and C. bousfieldi ) but are distinct species according to other morphological criteria. Consequently , a more thorough morphological analysis of the genetically most divergent populations of C. islandicus is needed in order to conclude about its potential species complex status .

The morphology points to a clade of C. islandicus , C. longicarpus , C. subterraneus , C. baculispina and C. packardi . C. baculispina and C. longicarpus have both a limited distribution, in Virginia and North Carolina whereas C. packardi has a wide range in central and eastern North America ( ). C. subterraneus is known from Britain , western and central Europe. The ancestor of such a clade may have inhabited the geographical region of Britain , Greenland and adjacent part of North America. The split may have occurred following the breakup of the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, first between Iceland and Scotland and later between Iceland-Greenland and the rest of North America. This is however incongruent with the molecular phylogenies, where C. islandicus and the North American Crangonyx species present an early divergence from the two other Eurasian species C. subterraneus and C. chlebnikovi , which are more closely related to the genus Bactrurus and Stygobromus . This incongruence between the trees based on molecular and morphological information might though be due to the limited subset of Crangonyx species included in the molecular phylogeny. Nonetheless the abundance of convergence in morphologic traits frequently observed in subterranean species lend more support to the hypotheses that C. islandicus is more related to the North American types than to those of mainland Europe. Such discrepancies are observed also when considering the morphological and molecular distances between C. chlebnikovi and C. forbesi . C. chlebnikovi distributed in Eurasia is more closely related morphologically to C. forbesi and the richmondensis group both of which have extensive distribution in North America. The richmondensis group is the most widely distributed group of Crangonyx in North America and the only group presenting native species from the Pacific Northwest ( ). The occurrence of C. chlebnikovi in Eurasia could be explained by the wide distribution of a hypothetical ancestor of C. chlebnikovi , C. forbesi and the richmondensis group in North America , Beringia and Eurasia. Nonetheless, the molecular analysis point at an early divergence of C. chlebnikovi from the North American Crangonyx species and it is more closely related to the Bactrurus and Stygobromus genera (Kornobis et al. 2011). Interestingly, noticed that C. serratus , which is closely related morphologically to the richmondensis group and to C. chlebnikovi , presents some morphological features close to Stygobromus and Bactrurus .

The overall poor association between the states of the characters defined by , scored for different species of the Crangonyctidae , and the clades observed in the molecular phylogenies indicate a high degree of homoplasy or convergent evolution among the distant genera. These morphological characters being defined for the classification of Crangonyx species from North America, may serve better to resolve evolutionary relationship within than among genera. The correlation between overall size and phylogenetic relationships among Crangonyx species , the potential phylogenetic information in length ratio of gnathopods segments, as well the length variation between Stygobromus and Bactrurus genus for uropod 3 and pereopod 6 and 7 observed by Koeneman and Holsinger (2001) indicate that morphometric analysis could be used to infer the phylogenetic relationships of the crangonyctids.

Morphological and molecular data are both supporting a divergence of C. islandicus from most other Crangonyx species , supporting the validity of the species. Based on molecular sequences of the 18S gene, its divergence from other species is similar as found between different genera. Although C. islandicus is characterized by unique morphological features it clusters with four other species in the large phylogeny based on morphology, showing the closest relationship with the gracilis group. The two data sets present different phylogenetic relationships between Eurasian and North American species of the genus Crangonyx . The convergence in the morphological characters, commonly observed among subterranean species, seems to be the most likely explanation for this discrepancy. A more comprehensive molecular analysis of the members of the Crangonyctidae is needed to solve its phylogenetic relationships but only a portion of the Crangonyx species have been studied so far. Of particular interest for comparison with C. islandicus are the morphologically similar North American species C. baculispina , C. longicarpus and C. packardi . Both the morphological and the molecular sequences show different degrees of variability which resolve the phylogenetic relationships differently at the different taxonomic levels. Furthermore as different markers may reflect different evolutionary histories, assessing variation in other genetic markers may be needed to give support to the observed phylogenetic relationships.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We want to thank Cene Fišer, Marc Arietti and Dmitry Sidorov for providing valuable samples and Gordan Karaman for his help during the scoring of particular characters. We are grateful to the University of Iceland Research Fund and the Icelandic Research Council (Rannís) for financial support. We are grateful to anonymous reviewers who made comments that improved the manuscript.

sec.title: Supplementary tables.
sec.p: TABLE A1 . Characters and character states used in this study as defined by Zhang & Holsinger (2003).
Mandible: segment 3 of palp
0: with more than 2 A and 2 B setae
1: with 1–2 A and/or 1–2 B setae only
Maxilla 1: number of apical plumose setae on inner plate
Maxilla 2: number of plumose setae on inner face of inner plate
Maxilliped: ratio of nail length:dactyl length of the palp
Gnathopod 1 of female: spine teeth on palmar margin of propod
0: notched
1: symmetrically notched
2: simple
Gnathopod 1 of female: defining angle of propod with strongly notched-serrate and/or serrate spine teeth
0: present
1: absent
Gnathopod 1 of female: teeth on inner margin of dactyl of propod and 1 tooth near the nail
0: with no other teeth
1: with a row of teeth or 1 to several teeth
Gnathopod 1 of female: propod 2 times or more larger than carpus
0: no
1: yes
Gnathopod 1 of female: number of superior medial setae per set
0: more than 2 setae
1: typically 1 seta only
Male and female with sexually dimorphic gnathopod 1
0: present
1: absent
Gnathopod 2 of female: spine teeth on palmar margin of propod
0: notched
1: symmetrically notched
2: simple
Gnathopod 2 of female: propod 2 times or more larger than carpus
0: no
1: yes
Gnathopod 2 of female: defining angle of propod with very distinctive notched-serrate and/or serrate spine teeth
0: absent
1: present
Gnathopod 2 of female: teeth on inner margin of dactyl of propod and 1 tooth near the nail
0: with no other teeth
1: with a row of teeth or 1 to several teeth
Male and female with sexually dimorphic gnathopod 2
0: present
1: absent
Gnathopod 2 of female: number of superior medial setae on propod per set
0: more than 2 setae
1: usually 1 seta only
Gnathopod 2 of female: palmar margin of propod with 2 or more rows of spine teeth per side or with more than 20 notched spine teeth per side
0: absent
1: present
Gnathopods of female: carpus slender, subequal or longer than propod
0: no
1: yes
Pleopod 1 of female: many setae along posterior margin of peduncle
0: present
1: absent
Pleopod 1 of female: number of retinaculae
Telson of female: number of spines on each dorsal lobe
Gnathopod 1 of male: defining angle of propod with notched-serrate and/or serrate spine teeth
0: present
1: absent
Gnathopod 2 of male: defining angle and palmar margin of propod with spine teeth similar to those described above in number 22.
0: yes
1: no
Gnathopods of male: spine teeth on palmar margin of propod
0: notched
1: mostly simple
2: rod like and unnotched
Outer ramus of male uropod 2 with comb spines
0: absent
1: present
Gnathopod 1 of male and female: defining angle with 1 row of spines on inside and 2 rows of non-serrate spine teeth on outside 0: absent
1: present

sec.title: Supplementary Figures
sec.p: FIGURE A1 . Phylogenetic relationships between Crangonyx species based on morphology. The tree is based on the characters defined by Zhang and Holsinger (2003), reconstructed by maximum parsimony and rooted with Synurella as outgroup.

FIGURE A2 . Phylogenetic relationships between Crangonyx species based on morphology. The tree is based on the characters defined by Zhang and Holsinger (2003), reconstructed by maximum parsimony and rooted with Crymostygius thingvallensis as outgroup.

FIGURE A3 . Comparison of molecular phylogeny based on the 18S and morphological characters for Crangonyctoidea species. The morphological characters states as defined by Zhang and Holsinger (2003) are displayed as following: white circle = 0, black circle =1, grey circle = 2, crossed circle = data not available. The species groups defined by Zhang and Holsinger (2003) are displayed on the right side.

FIGURE A4 . Comparison between molecular phylogeny based on the 28S and morphological characters for Crangonyctoidea species (modified from Kornobis et al. 2011). The morphological characters states as defined by Zhang & Holsinger (2003) are displayed as following: white circle = 0, black circle =1, grey circle = 2, crossed circle = Data not available. The species groups defined by Zhang and Holsinger (2003) are displayed on the right side.
